conclusion: Understand what a velocity-time graph tells us.
Velocity is on the y-axis and time on the x-axis; area under the curve gives displacement.
Assume positive direction is downward.
Calculate area under the curve from t=10 to t=15 seconds to find distance.
Velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s from t=0 to t=10 seconds.
Velocity peaks at 20 m/s at t=10 seconds.
Velocity decreases from 20 m/s to 10 m/s from t=10 to t=15 seconds.
Velocity levels off at around 10 m/s after t=15 seconds.
Estimate shape of curve from t=10 to t=15 seconds as a straight line.
Area under the curve is a trapezoid.
Formula for area of a trapezoid: (average of two parallel sides) × height.
Calculate average velocity: (20 m/s + 10 m/s) / 2 = 15 m/s.
Time interval is 5 seconds.
Distance = average velocity × time = 15 m/s × 5 s = 75 meters.
Consider if graph is perfectly linear or has curvature.
Graph appears linear between t=10 and t=15 seconds.
Area should be a trapezoid with bases 20 m/s and 10 m/s, height 5 seconds.
Consider using calculus to integrate velocity function over time.
Express velocity function as v(t) = mt + b.
Calculate slope m = -2 m/s².
Determine v(t) = -2t + 40.
Integrate v(t) from t=10 to t=15 to find distance.
Calculate distance: 75 meters.
Question if distance is greater or less than 75 meters.
